full_text: Normal staff can access the /admin dashboard. They don't even have admin role but they can still see all reports.
Customer A can see the invoice of customer B. Just by changing the invoice ID in the URL.
Viewer role can delete records. They should only be able to read, not modify anything.
User can read another user's profile. Just by guessing the user ID they get the whole profile data.
If I change ?userId=10 to 11 I can see another account's data. There is no permission check.
Mobile app lets me access other tenant's data. API does not filter by tenant ID.
Helpdesk user can escalate themselves to admin via an API call. That's not supposed to happen.
Soft-deleted records can still be accessed via direct URL. The backend does not check if it's deleted.
Tenant isolation is broken. Company A can see Company B's project list.
Unauthenticated user can call /export-all-users. They can dump all user accounts without login.
Intern role can approve financial transactions. They should not have approval permissions.
User can access /admin/logs without being logged in. This endpoint is unprotected.
Login works with weird payload. When I type ' OR 1=1 -- the login bypasses authentication.
Search bar shows weird symbols. SQL error appears in response when using %$#@.
Attacker sent id=1; DROP TABLE users; This caused table deletion.
Logs show syntax error near 'OR'. Attacker keeps sending strange SQL payloads.
Comment form allows <script>alert(1)</script>. Other users see the popup.
We found UNION SELECT payloads in logs. Looks like SQL injection.
API filter parameter accepts OR 1=1. It reveals data that shouldn't be visible.
Password reset parameter can inject SQL. User added ' OR ''=' in the link.
Search page reflects HTML without escaping. User injected raw HTML tags.
Backend executes OS commands from user input. Saw ; rm -rf / in the logs.
Attacker sent malicious serialized Java object. Possible remote code execution.
Login page throws DB error. Payload was '/**/OR/**/1=1'.
Any 6 digit code is accepted as OTP. Even random numbers work.
Session never expires. User stays logged in for days even without activity.
User stays logged in even after password reset. Session is not invalidated.
JWT tokens never expire. They have no exp claim.
Passwords stored in plaintext in DB. No hashing at all.
Login doesn't lock after hundreds of failed attempts. Brute force seems possible.
User can reuse previous password. Old revoked passwords accepted.
Remember-me cookie works on every device. It is not device-bound.
Reset password link has no expiration. Anyone with link can reset any time.
2FA is optional for admin accounts. Admins can skip MFA entirely.
Same session ID before and after login. Session fixation possible.
System uses md5 without salt for passwords. Very weak password storage.
Credit card numbers appear in access logs. Full PAN, not masked.
Customer SSNs accidentally exposed. They were in a CSV we emailed.
DB backup with PII left in public S3 bucket. Anyone could download it.
Export API returns full card numbers. No masking applied.
HR staff can download everyone's salary. No restrictions.
Error page prints full stack trace including secrets. This reveals environment vars.
Logs include Authorization headers. Bearer tokens visible.
National ID returned fully in frontend response. Should be masked.
Login page is HTTP, not HTTPS. Credentials sent in plain text.
TLS certificate expired 3 months ago. Browser warning appears.
Browser shows NOT SECURE on login page. TLS misconfigured.
We use self-signed certificate in production. Users see warnings.
Server still supports TLS 1.0. Weak cipher suites.
Hard-coded AES key '123456' in source code. Extremely weak encryption.
Tokens hashed using md5 without salt. Not secure.
TLS was disabled after update. Everything sent over HTTP.
Admin panel still uses default credentials. Username: admin, password: admin.
Directory listing enabled on production. Users can browse source files.
Debug mode enabled in production. Shows stack traces to public.
Kibana is exposed to the internet. No authentication required.
Test endpoints still active in production. /test/debug-health.
Firewall allows SSH from anywhere. 0.0.0.0/0 allowed.
S3 bucket is public read/write. Anyone can upload or delete.
WAF disabled after deployment. Forgot to turn back on.
CORS set to * for everything. Very risky.
Stack trace shows to all users. Happens on every error.
Monitoring dashboard public. No login required.
Default accounts still active. guest/guest still works.
Website is super slow. No logs, no suspicious activity.
UI looks bad. User wants nicer colors.
User forgot password. No security incident.
Boss says we are hacked. But no logs or evidence.
User spamming emojis in support chat. Annoying but not security.
User mistyped email. No deeper issue.
We changed domain; users are confused. Just usability issue.
Customer angry about pricing. Not a cyber issue.
